programs so as Andy mentioned I'm cognitive scientist and I study
computational problems that are easier for people than they are for machines so
there's been a lot of exciting recent progress in AI and machine learning yet for most types of everyday cognitive
abilities people are still better learners and thinkers than machines are
and by everyday cognitive ability I mean things like concept learning asking a
question understanding a scene or tasks that involve creativity general-purpose
problem solving reasoning language understanding speech recognition and so on and my research has two main goals to
better understand people and also to try to build a more human-like learning capacity in machines and today I'm gonna
focus on two of the abilities on this slide I'm gonna focus on concept learning and asking questions for
concept learning for me the motivating question is how do people learn such rich concepts from very little data
imagine this is your first time seeing a Segway you just see that image of a Segway at the top of the screen that
single image might be enough information for you to basically get what the concept of a Segway is and you can
recognize it again even if its features or its appearance have changed and be
able to rule out other distractors that share some properties in common with the original image so this ability is often
called one-shot learning it's been of interest to cognitive scientists and and AI researchers for a long time in
addition to learning very quickly people also seem to learn very rich representation so by the time that you
can recognize a Segway you can do many other things with that concept with that mental representation you can use it the
parse an object into its most important parts and relations you could use it to generate new examples you could sketch
your own version of a Segway or you could even generate a new concept so if you take a Segway and a motorcycle and a
unicycle and combine them together you could think up or imagine new vehicles like like the one on this life
so how do people do this how do they learn rich concepts from small amounts of experience and it's interesting to
contrast this with some of the the biggest breakthroughs in machine learning and AI particularly in in the
space of object recognition where we have these deep neural networks that are trained on very large amounts of data so

concept learning as a type of program induction and there's some key ingredients for learning good programs
and I'll tell you a little bit about what these ingredients are I've mentioned them earlier compositionality
causality and learning to learn the first ingredient this compositionality and this is this old idea that
representations can be constructed from a combination of parts and primitives so if you know about vehicles and you know
about wheels and handlebars and posts and seats and motors and how these different parts relate to one another
when you see a Segway for the first time if you parse it into these parts and relations it gives you a rich representation that can help you pick
out new examples of the same concept so that's that's the compositionality idea this the second ingredient is about
causality and it's this idea that generative models at an abstract level can capture real causal structure where
the data comes from in the world and this is an observation about digits from
hinted in there where they pointed out that these twos they differ a lot in pixel space they may not share many
pixels in common but they're very similar in motor space basically the same move
produces all those different twos on on the screen and that could be a better
representation for generalization you can also think about a concept like a tree where you could find features to
help you recognize it and identify trees but there's also some deeper causal structure there about how trees grow in
terms of branches growing and then the branches themselves branching and we
have a lot of additional knowledge beyond just features that we use to recognize it and the third ingredient is
what we call learning to learn which is this idea that you become better at learning concepts as you learn more of
them so in terms of handwritten characters the the model learns a lot about the structure of of letters in
general so it's trained on about half of Omniglot where it gets a lot of experience with letters and knows about
how many strokes tend to be in letters and where's the strokes tend to start like the first strokes tenth tends to
start in the top left and the second stroke tends to be a little bit more diffuse and so on it learns about motor
primitives in terms of some basic movements that people tend to use when they're producing letters it learns
about how much your affine transformation there is from one person running it to the next it learns about
different relations and and what when strokes tend to attach to one another and and what the different sort of types
of relations are so those are what we mean by learning to learn with this type of knowledge it can help you become a
better learner so the model is pre-training Don on letters from other alphabets and then tested on new ones so
